content.text: Use the ruler in Fig. 1.1 to find the length of the piece of cotton
The left-hand end of the cotton is moved to the 1.0cm mark on the ruler
On Fig. 1.1, mark clearly and carefully, with an arrow, where the **right-hand** end will reach on the ruler.
The piece of cotton is wound around a wooden rod
The rod has a square cross-section. The cotton goes around the rod exactly 3 times, as shown in Fig. 1.2
Calculate the thickness of the square wooden rod
thickness =   .........  \(cm\)
A ruler is used to measure the length of a piece of cotton, as shown in Fig. 1.1
which form of energy decreases,
which form of energy increases?
During the run up the hill,
State the three quantities that need to be known in order to calculate the useful power of one of the athletes
The two athletes run side-by-side all the way to the top of the hill, but one athlete develops more useful power than the other
Suggest a reason for this difference
Fig. 2.1 shows two athletes training for a race
They run up a hill at steady speed
Explain why there is a delay between seeing and hearing the explosion
The girl is standing \(1700 \text{m}\) from the explosion site \(\mathbf{X}\)
Calculate the speed of sound
speed of sound =   .........
The girl hears the explosion 5.0 s after she sees the explosion happening
When does he hear the explosion? Tick one box
immediately it happens
before the girl
at the same time as the girl
later than the girl
How does the sound heard by the boy compare with the sound heard by the girl?
Tick one box
The sound heard by the boy is quieter
The sounds are equally loud
The sound heard by the boy is louder
The boy is standing at \(\mathbf{Y}\), between the explosion site and the girl
An explosion at \(\mathbf{X}\) in a quarry is heard by a boy at \(\mathbf{Y}\) and a girl at \(\mathbf{Z}\). Their relative position are shown in Fig. 3.1

What does this instrument measure?

What happens within the instrument to make it give a reading larger than zero?

mark carefully with a clear cross, labelled I, where the image of the object is located,
draw the path of a ray from the object to point P on the mirror, and its path after the ray is incident on the mirror,
mark clearly the angle of incidence \(i\) and the angle of reflection \(r\) at P
Fig. 5.1 shows a small object in front of a vertical plane mirror
On Fig. 5.1,
When you look into a mirror, you see an image of your face
State two characteristics of the image you see
If you look from a brightly-lit room into a thick glass window when it is dark outside, you can see two images of your face
Suggest why there are two images
How will the two threads appear? Tick one box
both still vertical
further apart at the bottom
closer together at the bottom
Explain your answer to (a)(i)
A and B are each given a positive charge
How will the two threads appear? Tick one box
both still vertical
further apart at the bottom
closer together at the bottom
Explain your answer to (b)(i)
The charge on A is made negative, but B remains positively charged
Ball A remains negatively charged and ball B remains positively charged. A ro<mark>large positive charge is positioned to the left of A
State what happens to A and to B
ball A
ball B
Fig. 6.1 shows two light, uncharged balls A and B suspended next to each other on insulating threads
Which one is involved when thermal energy is transferred through a solid?
Which one can occur only in a liquid or a gas?
Which two are impossible in a vacuum?
Three methods of transfer of thermal energy are conduction, convection and radiation
List these regions in order of decreasing wavelength. The first one has been filled in for you
longest wavelength
shortest wavelength
Where in this list would you insert microwaves?
A microwave oven is one device that makes use of microwaves
Explain why the design of microwave ovens must include effective screening, so that microwaves do not escape

gamma,
infra-red,
radio,

visible,

at R?

What value will the ammeter show when it is inserted

potential difference =   .........  V

resistance =   .........  \(\Omega\)
What happens to the current in the circuit when the resistance of X is increased?
A 6.0V battery is connected as shown in the circuit of Fig. 9.1
What is the potential difference across the LDR when it is dark? Tick one box
0V
greater than 0V but less than 6.0V
exactly 6.0V
greater than 6.0V but less than 12.0V
Fig. 10.1 shows a light-dependent resistor (LDR) connected with a \(1000 \Omega\) resistor form a potential divider
In daylight, the LDR has a resistance much lower than \(1000 \Omega\)
In the dark, the LDR has a resistance much higher than \(1000 \Omega\)
At a certain time, the potential difference across the relay coil is greater than 6.0V
Describe how this potential difference causes the switch to close
What happens to the lamp when the switch in the relay is closed?
Fig. 10.2 shows the potential divider of Fig. 10.1 connected to a relay and a lamp
In order to close the switch in the relay, there must be at least 6.0V across the relay coil
The circuit of Fig. 10.2 is positioned in a laboratory
Use your answers to **(a)** and **(b)** to deduce the condition in the laboratory that will cause the lamp to glow. Complete the sentence below
The lamp will glow when

change in temperature
change in light level
change in sound level
change in air pressure
change in background radiation
